newsitem.title: FRANCE: SOCCER-GINOLA SAYS HE STILL HAS SOMETHING TO OFFER FRANCE.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-GINOLA SAYS HE STILL HAS SOMETHING TO OFFER FRANCE.

text.p: David Ginola, who played a significant role in Newcastle's 5-0 premier league rout of Manchester United on Sunday, believes he still has something to offer France at international level.
But he does not rate his chances of a recall too highly.
"For me to be recalled to the French team one day, I'm going to have to do some extraordinary things," he said in an interview published in the sports daily L'Equipe on Tuesday.
"They're trying to build a new team but, at 29, one can offer a lot: one has international experience...I'm more mature, more steady in my head, I analyse situations better."
Ginola, hurt in the past by criticism in his home country, played one of his last internationals in harrowing circumstances three years ago.

With France's qualification for the 1994 World Cup finals in the bag in the dying seconds of a 1-1 draw with Bulgaria in Paris in November 1993, Ginola lost posession and allowed the Bulgarians to snatch a winner and a U.S. berth at their expense.
Ginola, a 68th minute substitute for Jean-Pierre Papin, was blamed for giving the ball away from a free kick. He was widely criticised in his home country and has been capped only once since.
Ginola admitted to some difficulty in adapting to the requirements of Newcastle manager Kevin Keegan this season.
Keegan wanted his winger to take on defensive responsibilities given the side play with two strikers in Alan Shearer and Les Ferdinand.
"On Friday I had a discussion with Keegan to remind him that in these last years I've given my best playing all out in attack," the former Paris Saint-Germain player said.
"(The result was) he asked me to play my favourite role."

A close season offer from Barcelona that fell through and Ginola's difficulty in holding down a first team place at Newcastle earlier in the season led to suggestions he was no longer happy in the northeast of England.
But Ginola refutes such suggestions, saying his relations with Keegan were as good as last season.
"I think Newcastle are ripe to become the team of the future in England," he said.
